data.title: About Halldór Laxness
data.meta_description: Halldór Laxness (1902–98) was an Icelandic novelist, poet and playwright. His novels include Sjálfstætt fólk/Independent People (1934–35), Heimsljós/World’s Light (1937–40), Íslandsklukkan/Iceland’s Bell (1943–46) and Kristnihald undir Jökli/Under the Glacier (1968). He was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1955. In 1927 he moved to Los Angeles hoping to become a screenwriter. He stayed for two years and the essay published here, ‘Kvikmyndin ameríska 1928’/‘The American Film in 1928’, was written during that period and appeared originally in 1929 in his essay collection 'Alþýðubókin/‘The Commoner’s Book’.'

Halldór Laxness (1902–98) was an Icelandic novelist, poet and playwright. His novels include Sjálfstætt fólk/Independent People (1934–35), Heimsljós/World’s Light (1937–40), Íslandsklukkan/Iceland’s Bell (1943–46) and Kristnihald undir Jökli/Under the Glacier (1968). He was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1955. In 1927 he moved to Los Angeles hoping to become a screenwriter. He stayed for two years and the essay published here, ‘Kvikmyndin ameríska 1928’/‘The American Film in 1928’, was written during that period and appeared originally in 1929 in his essay collection 'Alþýðubókin/‘The Commoner’s Book’.'
